posts.content:
"Update for Chrome: Enhancing Security Against Remote Code Execution Vulnerabilities"

Google Chrome has recently been updated across Windows, Mac, and Linux platforms, with the latest versions being 122.0.6261.111/.112 for Windows and Mac, and 122.0.6261.111 for Linux. This update incorporates several security fixes. It addresses high issues such as memory access vulnerabilities and other potential threats. Noteworthy fixes include a high-severity out-of-bounds memory access flaw, a misimplementation in the V8 engine, and a use-after-free vulnerability in FedCM.

For users on versions before 122.0.6261.111/112, it is strongly advised to update Google Chrome to ensure protection against these vulnerabilities.

#CyberSecurity #GoogleChrome #VulnerabilityManagement #RCE #CVE20242173 #CVE20242174 #CVE20242176 #UpdateNow

For more detailed information, please refer to the official announcements on Google Chrome Releases and HKCERT. 🌍🔒🛡️

VMware security advisory for VMware ESXi, Workstation, and Fusion. No mention of exploitation.

  • CVE-2024-22252 (9.3 critical) Use-after-free vulnerability in XHCI USB controller
  • CVE-2024-22253 (9.3 critical) Use-after-free vulnerability in UHCI USB controller
  • CVE-2024-22254 (7.9 high) ESXi Out-of-bounds write vulnerability
  • CVE-2024-22255 (7.1 high) Information disclosure vulnerability in UHCI USB controller

posts.content: Tracked as CVE-2024-22252 and CVE-2024-22253, the vulnerabilities have been described as use-after-free bugs in the XHCI USB controller. They carry a CVSS score of 9.3 for Workstation and Fusion, and 8.4 for ESXi systems. https://thehackernews.com/2024/03/vmware-issues-security-patches-for-esxi.html

CVE-2024-22252.description: VMware ESXi, Workstation, and Fusion contain a use-after-free vulnerability in the XHCI USB controller. A malicious actor with local administrative privileges on a virtual machine may exploit this issue to execute code as the virtual machine's VMX process running on the host. On ESXi, the exploitation is contained within the VMX sandbox whereas, on Workstation and Fusion, this may lead to code execution on the machine where Workstation or Fusion is installed.

posts.content:
Apple released additional security advisories, each one containing one or both of the recently disclosed exploited zero-days CVE-2024-23225 and CVE-2024-23296, which were added to the CISA KEV Catalog on 06 March 2024:

  • About the security content of macOS Monterey 12.7.4
  • About the security content of macOS Sonoma 14.4
  • About the security content of macOS Ventura 13.6.5
  • About the security content of tvOS 17.4
  • About the security content of visionOS 1.1
  • About the security content of watchOS 10.4

Edit: About the security content of Safari 17.4
 nothing exploited.

No new zero-days.

#Apple #zeroday #vulnerability #activeexploitation #eitw #CVE_2024_23225 #CVE_2024_23296 #CISA #KnownExploitedVulnerabilitiesCatalog #KEV #vulnerability

posts.content:
Apple zero-days:

  • CVE-2024-23225: memory corruption in Kernel allowed for bypassing kernel memory protections
  • CVE-2024-23296: memory corruption in RTKit allowed for bypassing kernel memory protections

Apple is aware of a report that this issue may have been exploited.

posts.content:
#iOS 17.4 includes 4 important #security fixes, 2 were exploited

Update ASAP.

Zero-day exploits for a kernel flaw (CVE-2024-23225) and RTKit flaw (CVE-2024-23296), both when exploited bypassed kernel memory protections have been patched by #Apple.

Also a #privacy patch included in the Accessibility feature (CVE-2024-23243); apps could read "sensitive location information" and a bug in Safari Private Browsing exposed locked tabs while switching tab groups (CVE-2024-23256).

Other security fixes are also included in iOS 17.4, but the additional CVE entries will be added later.

#cybersecurity #update #exploitation #cve

https://9to5mac.com/2024/03/05/ios-17-4-fixes-4-security-flaws/

posts.content:
"🚨 ScreenConnect Exploits Unleash ToddleShark Malware by Kimsuky 🚨"

Kimsuky, the North Korean APT, leverages vulnerabilities in ScreenConnect (CVE-2024-1708 & CVE-2024-1709) to deploy ToddleShark, aiming at espionage. This polymorphic malware uses Microsoft binaries for stealth and conducts extensive data theft. It's an evolution of Kimsuky's espionage toolkit, hinting at their refined strategies for long-term intelligence gathering. ToddleShark manipulates registry settings, employs scheduled tasks for persistence, and exfiltrates data using PEM certificates, showcasing advanced obfuscation and evasion techniques. Be vigilant and patch up!

#CyberSecurity #APT #NorthKorea #Malware #ScreenConnect #CVE2024_1708 #CVE2024_1709 #ToddleShark #Kimsuky #DataTheft #Espionage #InfoSec

Source: BleepingComputer.com

Mitre - Kimsuky

posts.content:
Sophos covers attacks involving the new ConnectWise ScreenConnect vulnerabilities. This includes a Lockbit ransomware variant (buhtiRansom) using the leaked builder tool in 2023. Other attacks involved dropping AsyncRAT, Rust infostealer, and Vidar/Redline stealer. One attack dropped another remote access client called SimpleHelp, followed up by CRYPT ransomware. There were also Cobalt Strike and Xworm payloads. Sophos provides threat hunting information. No IOC.
🔗 https://news.sophos.com/en-us/2024/02/23/connectwise-screenconnect-attacks-deliver-malware/

🚨 Just launched: FREE scanner for #SlashAndGrab 🥷, the ConnectWise ScreenConnect vulnerabilities: https://pentest-tools.com/network-vulnerability-scanning/connectwise-screenconnect-cve-2024-1709-vulnerability-scanner

When John Hammond started posting about CVE-2024-1709 (CVSSv3 10) & CVE-2024-1708 (CVSSv3 8.4), we instantly picked up on them.

Our team moved fast and added detection for both CVEs, knowing attackers are actively trying to use them (CVE-2024-1709 especially) to bypass security controls and gain unrestricted system access.

We also turned it into a FREE tool for any pentester to use: https://pentest-tools.com/network-vulnerability-scanning/connectwise-screenconnect-cve-2024-1709-vulnerability-scanner

posts.content:
@austinlarsen @simontsui nbd, you're not the only one.

I'm still on the (now somewhat passive) hunt for any real evidence of exploitation for the other one. Lots of conjecture, loads of hits for CVE-2024-1709, but nothing solid for CVE-2024-1708. Every news outlet seems to just conflate the two and sometimes gets them backwards.

posts.content:
@campuscodi one question I have is, do they even need to exploit CVE-2024-1708? With CVE-2024-1709, they create an admin user on the ScreenConnect server, giving them full control. This is a one character cheat, whereas 1708 requires user interaction and privileges (CVSS:3.1/AV:N/AC:L/PR:H/UI:R/S:C/C:H/I:H/A:H)

I don't specifically see it in the Trend Micro article, but is there actual evidence of CVE-2024-1708 exploitation? Since unpatched versions of ScreenConnect are vulnerable to both 1708 and 1709, it's almost certainly going to make 1709 the more valuable exploit.

posts.content:
"🚨 ScreenConnect Exploits Unleash ToddleShark Malware by Kimsuky 🚨"

Kimsuky, the North Korean APT, leverages vulnerabilities in ScreenConnect (CVE-2024-1708 & CVE-2024-1709) to deploy ToddleShark, aiming at espionage. This polymorphic malware uses Microsoft binaries for stealth and conducts extensive data theft. It's an evolution of Kimsuky's espionage toolkit, hinting at their refined strategies for long-term intelligence gathering. ToddleShark manipulates registry settings, employs scheduled tasks for persistence, and exfiltrates data using PEM certificates, showcasing advanced obfuscation and evasion techniques. Be vigilant and patch up!

#CyberSecurity #APT #NorthKorea #Malware #ScreenConnect #CVE2024_1708 #CVE2024_1709 #ToddleShark #Kimsuky #DataTheft #Espionage #InfoSec

Source: BleepingComputer.com

Mitre - Kimsuky

posts.content:
Sophos covers attacks involving the new ConnectWise ScreenConnect vulnerabilities. This includes a Lockbit ransomware variant (buhtiRansom) using the leaked builder tool in 2023. Other attacks involved dropping AsyncRAT, Rust infostealer, and Vidar/Redline stealer. One attack dropped another remote access client called SimpleHelp, followed up by CRYPT ransomware. There were also Cobalt Strike and Xworm payloads. Sophos provides threat hunting information. No IOC.
🔗 https://news.sophos.com/en-us/2024/02/23/connectwise-screenconnect-attacks-deliver-malware/

🚨 Just launched: FREE scanner for #SlashAndGrab 🥷, the ConnectWise ScreenConnect vulnerabilities: https://pentest-tools.com/network-vulnerability-scanning/connectwise-screenconnect-cve-2024-1709-vulnerability-scanner

When John Hammond started posting about CVE-2024-1709 (CVSSv3 10) & CVE-2024-1708 (CVSSv3 8.4), we instantly picked up on them.

We also turned it into a FREE tool for any pentester to use: https://pentest-tools.com/network-vulnerability-scanning/connectwise-screenconnect-cve-2024-1709-vulnerability-scanner

posts.content:
@austinlarsen @simontsui nbd, you're not the only one.

I'm still on the (now somewhat passive) hunt for any real evidence of exploitation for the other one. Lots of conjecture, loads of hits for CVE-2024-1709, but nothing solid for CVE-2024-1708. Every news outlet seems to just conflate the two and sometimes gets them backwards.

posts.content:
@campuscodi one question I have is, do they even need to exploit CVE-2024-1708? With CVE-2024-1709, they create an admin user on the ScreenConnect server, giving them full control. This is a one character cheat, whereas 1708 requires user interaction and privileges (CVSS:3.1/AV:N/AC:L/PR:H/UI:R/S:C/C:H/I:H/A:H)

I don't specifically see it in the Trend Micro article, but is there actual evidence of CVE-2024-1708 exploitation? Since unpatched versions of ScreenConnect are vulnerable to both 1708 and 1709, it's almost certainly going to make 1709 the more valuable exploit.

posts.content:
In tracking the origins of exploitation leading up to their KEV Catalog additions:

  • I previously informed the CISA Vulnerability Management Team of potential exploitation of CVE-2021-36380 as part of an IZ1H9 Mirai-based DDoS campaign reported by Fortinet on 09 October 2023. What they do with that information is up to them.
  • The Pixel Update Bulletin published 13 June 2023 included an announcement that read "Note: There are indications that CVE-2023-21237 may be under limited, targeted exploitation."

#CISA #KEV #KnownExploitedVulnerabilitiesCatalog #eitw #activeexploitation #vulnerability #CVE_2023_21237 #CVE_2021_36380

posts.content:
Cado Security reports an emerging malware campaign targeting misconfigured servers running Apache Hadoop YARN, Docker, Atlassian Confluence and Redis for cryptocurrency mining. The campaign uses Golang-based malware that automate the discovery and infection of hosts. Confluence RCE vulnerability CVE-2022-26134 is exploited. Cado describes initial infection and the four Golang payloads. IOC provided.
🔗 https://www.cadosecurity.com/spinning-yarn-a-new-linux-malware-campaign-targets-docker-apache-hadoop-redis-and-confluence/

#threatintel #Apache #Hadoop #Redis #Docker #Confluence #Golang #IOC #cybercrime #cryptojacking #cryptominer #CVE_2022_26134 #XMRig

posts.content: Scanning for Confluence CVE-2022-26134 https://i5c.us/d30704

CVE-2022-26134.description: In affected versions of Confluence Server and Data Center, an OGNL injection vulnerability exists that would allow an unauthenticated attacker to execute arbitrary code on a Confluence Server or Data Center instance. The affected versions are from 1.3.0 before 7.4.17, from 7.13.0 before 7.13.7, from 7.14.0 before 7.14.3, from 7.15.0 before 7.15.2, from 7.16.0 before 7.16.4, from 7.17.0 before 7.17.4, and from 7.18.0 before 7.18.1.

posts.content:
ASEC reports that financially motivated threat actor z0Miner targets Korean Oracle WebLogic servers to cryptomine. z0Miner is known to exploit Oracle RCE vulnerabilities CVE-2020-14882 and CVE-2020-14883. ASEC provides the attack chain, from exploiting the vulnerabilities to deploy webshells, to using Fast Reverse Proxy (FRP) for Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) communication. Apache ActiveMQ vulnerability CVE-2023-46604 is also exploited. Netcat and AnyDesk are downloaded, and XMrig is used for mining. ASEC provides IOC, Monero Wallet and Mining Pool Address.
🔗 https://asec.ahnlab.com/en/62564/

#cybercrime #cryptojacking #threatintel #IOC #CVE_2020_14882 #CVE_2020_14883 #FRP #CVE_2023_46696 #z0Miner

CVE-2020-14882.description: Vulnerability in the Oracle WebLogic Server product of Oracle Fusion Middleware (component: Console). Supported versions that are affected are 10.3.6.0.0, 12.1.3.0.0, 12.2.1.3.0, 12.2.1.4.0 and 14.1.1.0.0. Easily exploitable vulnerability allows unauthenticated attacker with network access via HTTP to compromise Oracle WebLogic Server. Successful attacks of this vulnerability can result in takeover of Oracle WebLogic Server. CVSS 3.1 Base Score 9.8 (Confidentiality, Integrity and Availability impacts). CVSS Vector: (CVSS:3.1/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2020-14883.description: Vulnerability in the Oracle WebLogic Server product of Oracle Fusion Middleware (component: Console). Supported versions that are affected are 10.3.6.0.0, 12.1.3.0.0, 12.2.1.3.0, 12.2.1.4.0 and 14.1.1.0.0. Easily exploitable vulnerability allows high privileged attacker with network access via HTTP to compromise Oracle WebLogic Server. Successful attacks of this vulnerability can result in takeover of Oracle WebLogic Server. CVSS 3.1 Base Score 7.2 (Confidentiality, Integrity and Availability impacts). CVSS Vector: (CVSS:3.1/AV:N/AC:L/PR:H/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).

posts.content:
Cisco security advisory for CVE-2024-20345 (6.5 medium) Cisco AppDynamics Controller Path Traversal Vulnerability could allow for directory traversal attacks by an authenticated remote attacker. This vulnerability is due to insufficient validation of user-supplied input. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by sending a crafted request to an affected device. A successful exploit could allow the attacker to access sensitive data on an affected device. Fixed in Cisco AppDynamics Controller Release 23.4.0. Cisco PSIRT is not aware of any public announcements or malicious use.
🔗 https://sec.cloudapps.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-appd-traversal-m7N8mZpF

#Cisco #securityadvisory #CVE_2024_20345 #vulnerability #AppDynamicsController

CVE-2024-20345.description:
A vulnerability in the file upload functionality of Cisco AppDynamics Controller could allow an authenticated, remote attacker to conduct directory traversal attacks on an affected device. 
 This vulnerability is due to insufficient validation of user-supplied input. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by sending a crafted request to an affected device. A successful exploit could allow the attacker to access sensitive data on an affected device.

posts.content:
Cisco released another 6 security advisories on 06 March 2024:

  • CVE-2024-20338 (7.3 high) Cisco Secure Client for Linux with ISE Posture Module Privilege Escalation Vulnerability
  • CVE-2024-20337 (8.2 high) Cisco Secure Client Carriage Return Line Feed Injection Vulnerability
  • CVE-2024-20335 (6.5 medium) Cisco Small Business 100, 300, and 500 Series Wireless APs Command Injection Vulnerability and CVE-2024-20336 (6.5 medium) Buffer Overflow Vulnerability
  • CVE-2024-20301 (6.2 medium) Cisco Duo Authentication for Windows Logon and RDP Authentication Bypass Vulnerability
  • CVE-2024-20292 (4.4 medium) Cisco Duo Authentication for Windows Logon and RDP Information Disclosure Vulnerability
  • CVE-2024-20346 (5.4 medium) Cisco AppDynamics Controller Cross-Site Scripting Vulnerability

The Cisco PSIRT is not aware of any public announcements or malicious use of the vulnerabilities that are described in these advisories.

CVE-2024-20338.description:
A vulnerability in the ISE Posture (System Scan) module of Cisco Secure Client for Linux could allow an authenticated, local attacker to elevate privileges on an affected device.
 This vulnerability is due to the use of an uncontrolled search path element. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by copying a malicious library file to a specific directory in the filesystem and persuading an administrator to restart a specific process. A successful exploit could allow the attacker to execute arbitrary code on an affected device with root privileges.

#Cisco #PatchTuesday #vulnerability #CVE_2024_20338 #CVE_2024_20337 #CVE_2024_20335 #CVE_2024_20336 #CVE_2024_20301 #CVE_2024_20292 #CVE_2024_20346

CVE-2024-20337.description:
A vulnerability in the SAML authentication process of Cisco Secure Client could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to conduct a carriage return line feed (CRLF) injection attack against a user. 
 This vulnerability is due to insufficient validation of user-supplied input. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by persuading a user to click a crafted link while establishing a VPN session. A successful exploit could allow the attacker to execute arbitrary script code in the browser or access sensitive, browser-based information, including a valid SAML token. The attacker could then use the token to establish a remote access VPN session with the privileges of the affected user. Individual hosts and services behind the VPN headend would still need additional credentials for successful access.

CVE-2024-20335.description: A vulnerability in the web-based management interface of Cisco Small Business 100, 300, and 500 Series Wireless APs could allow an authenticated, remote attacker to perform command injection attacks against an affected device. In order to exploit this vulnerability, the attacker must have valid administrative credentials for the device. This vulnerability is due to insufficient validation of user-supplied input. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by sending a crafted HTTP request to the web-based management interface of an affected device. A successful exploit could allow the attacker to execute arbitrary code as the root user on the underlying operating system.

  • CVE-2024-20337 (8.2 high) Cisco Secure Client Carriage Return Line Feed Injection Vulnerability
  • CVE-2024-20335 (6.5 medium) Cisco Small Business 100, 300, and 500 Series Wireless APs Command Injection Vulnerability and CVE-2024-20336 (6.5 medium) Buffer Overflow Vulnerability
  • CVE-2024-20301 (6.2 medium) Cisco Duo Authentication for Windows Logon and RDP Authentication Bypass Vulnerability
  • CVE-2024-20292 (4.4 medium) Cisco Duo Authentication for Windows Logon and RDP Information Disclosure Vulnerability
  • CVE-2024-20346 (5.4 medium) Cisco AppDynamics Controller Cross-Site Scripting Vulnerability

The Cisco PSIRT is not aware of any public announcements or malicious use of the vulnerabilities that are described in these advisories.

#Cisco #PatchTuesday #vulnerability #CVE_2024_20338 #CVE_2024_20337 #CVE_2024_20335 #CVE_2024_20336 #CVE_2024_20301 #CVE_2024_20292 #CVE_2024_20346

CVE-2024-20301.description:
A vulnerability in Cisco Duo Authentication for Windows Logon and RDP could allow an authenticated, physical attacker to bypass secondary authentication and access an affected Windows device. 
 This vulnerability is due to a failure to invalidate locally created trusted sessions after a reboot of the affected device. An attacker with primary user credentials could exploit this vulnerability by attempting to authenticate to an affected device. A successful exploit could allow the attacker to access the affected device without valid permissions.

CVE-2024-20292.description:
A vulnerability in the logging component of Cisco Duo Authentication for Windows Logon and RDP could allow an authenticated, local attacker to view sensitive information in clear text on an affected system. 

 This vulnerability is due to improper storage of an unencrypted registry key in certain logs. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by accessing the logs on an affected system. A successful exploit could allow the attacker to view sensitive information in clear text.

CVE-2024-20346.description:
A vulnerability in the web-based management interface of Cisco AppDynamics Controller could allow an authenticated, remote attacker to perform a reflected cross-site scripting (XSS) attack against a user of the interface of an affected device.

 This vulnerability is due to insufficient validation of user-supplied input by the web-based management interface. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by persuading a user to click a malicious link. A successful exploit could allow the attacker to execute arbitrary script code in the context of the affected interface or access sensitive, browser-based information.

posts.content:
Microsoft Security Response Center (MSRC) posts 4 Chromium security advisories that were initially disclosed by Google on 05 March 2024. The new one is CVE-2024-26167 (4.3 medium) Microsoft Edge for Android Spoofing Vulnerability, which contains substantially more information than Chrome does in their advisory. It is marked Not Exploited, Not Publicly disclosed, and Exploitation Less Likely. Interestingly there's a mistake in their FAQ section, where they state both confidentiality and integrity as Low and Availability as None. However, the Metric shows C:N, I:L, A:N which scores as 4.3 medium in a CVSSv3 calculator, whereas C:L, I:L, A:N = 5.4 medium. Nitpicking but I'm all about attention to detail, especially after Microsoft botched the announcement of several exploited zero-days in the month of February 2024.
🔗 https://msrc.microsoft.com/update-guide/en-US/advisory/CVE-2024-26167

#Microsoft #MSRC #vulnerability #CVE_2024_26167 #Chromium #spoofing

posts.content:
Progress security advisory: CVE-2024-1403 (10.0 critical!) authentication bypass in OpenEdge Authentication Gateway and AdminServer. The vulnerability is a bypass to authentication based on a failure to properly handle username and password. Fixed in OpenEdge LTS Update 11.7.19, 12.2.14 and 12.8.1. No mention of exploitation.
🔗 https://community.progress.com/s/article/Important-Critical-Alert-for-OpenEdge-Authentication-Gateway-and-AdminServer

CVE-2024-1403.description:
In OpenEdge Authentication Gateway and AdminServer prior to 11.7.19, 12.2.14, 12.8.1 on all platforms supported by the OpenEdge product, an authentication bypass vulnerability has been identified.  The
vulnerability is a bypass to authentication based on a failure to properly
handle username and password.  Certain unexpected
content passed into the credentials can lead to unauthorized access without proper
authentication.

posts.content:
Computer Weekly takes interest in the JetBrains-Rapid7 feud. "At the core of the disagreement lies a difference in approaches to vulnerability disclosure and patching." They neglected to mention JetBrains's explicitly stating "At this point, we made a decision not to make a coordinated disclosure with Rapid7"
🔗 https://www.computerweekly.com/news/366572453/Rapid7-hits-out-over-botched-vulnerability-disclosure

Shoutout to @todb who was quoted from a 2022 Rapid7 blog post:

With this in mind, said Beardsley, silent patching in fact limits knowledge of the patched vulnerability to skilled exploit developers, that is to say threat actors, so while it is true that silent patching cuts out casual, low-skilled hackers and script kiddies, it also excludes the good guys, legitimate pen testers, the developers of defensive technologies, incident responders, and the entire cyber community who might benefit from being able to understand the issue better and communicate it effectively.

#JetBrains #TeamCity #vulnerability #securityadvisory #CVE_2024_27198 #CVE_2024_27199 #Rapid7 #Poc #proofofconcept

posts.content:
Why you should care about the new JetBrains TeamCity authentication bypass vulnerability CVE-2024-27198 (9.8 critical):

  • On 18 October 2023, Microsoft observed North Korean state-sponsored APTs Diamond Sleet (aka Lazarus Group, publicly attributed to 110 Research Center 3rd Technical Surveillance Bureau of Reconnaissance General Bureau by the US Government) and Onyx Sleet (aka Andariel, also publicly attributed to RGB by the US Government) exploiting a similar JetBrains TeamCity authentication bypass vulnerability CVE-2023-42793.
  • On 13 December 2023, CISA published a cybersecurity advisory reporting that the Russian state-sponsored APT29 (Cozy Bear, publicly attributed to Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR) by the USG) was mass-exploiting CVE-2023-42793 since September 2023.
  • From public disclosure to proof of concept was 6 days. Exploitation was within 7 days after that (KEV Catalog in 15 days). Nation-state abuse within 12-22 days of public disclosure.

#JetBrains #TeamCity #vulnerability #securityadvisory #CVE_2024_27198 #CVE_2024_27199 #Rapid7 #Poc #proofofconcept

posts.content:
JetBrains tries to save face by responding to Rapid7's blog post with clarifications. It comes off accusatory and defends their attempt to silently patch. cc: @catc0n @campuscodi @serghei @jgreig
🔗 https://blog.jetbrains.com/teamcity/2024/03/our-approach-addressing-recently-discovered-vulnerabilities-in-teamcity-on-premises/

To reiterate, we never had any intention to release a fix silently without making the full details public. As a CVE Numbering Authority (CNA), we assigned CVE IDs for both issues a day after receiving the report.

We suggested disclosing the details of the vulnerabilities in the same way we have followed in the past (with a time delay between releasing a fix and making a full disclosure), which allows our customers to upgrade their TeamCity instances.

This suggestion was rejected by the Rapid7 team who published full details of the vulnerabilities (and how to exploit them) a few hours after we had released a fix to TeamCity customers.

#JetBrains #TeamCity #vulnerability #securityadvisory #CVE_2024_27198 #CVE_2024_27199 #Rapid7 #Poc #proofofconcept

posts.content:
Rapid7 provides technical analyses into JetBrains TeamCity vulnerabilities CVE-2024-27198 and CVE-2024-27199, both of which they consider to be authentication bypasses. They provide what are effectively Proofs of Concept, even if the words "poc" or "proof" aren't used. Rapid7 notes what an indicator of compromise would appear as for CVE-2024-27198. Timeline has an interesting exchange between JetBrains and Rapid7 regarding silent patching.
🔗 https://www.rapid7.com/blog/post/2024/03/04/etr-cve-2024-27198-and-cve-2024-27199-jetbrains-teamcity-multiple-authentication-bypass-vulnerabilities-fixed/

posts.content:
Computer Weekly takes interest in the JetBrains-Rapid7 feud. "At the core of the disagreement lies a difference in approaches to vulnerability disclosure and patching." They neglected to mention JetBrains's explicitly stating "At this point, we made a decision not to make a coordinated disclosure with Rapid7"
🔗 https://www.computerweekly.com/news/366572453/Rapid7-hits-out-over-botched-vulnerability-disclosure

Shoutout to @todb who was quoted from a 2022 Rapid7 blog post:

With this in mind, said Beardsley, silent patching in fact limits knowledge of the patched vulnerability to skilled exploit developers, that is to say threat actors, so while it is true that silent patching cuts out casual, low-skilled hackers and script kiddies, it also excludes the good guys, legitimate pen testers, the developers of defensive technologies, incident responders, and the entire cyber community who might benefit from being able to understand the issue better and communicate it effectively.

#JetBrains #TeamCity #vulnerability #securityadvisory #CVE_2024_27198 #CVE_2024_27199 #Rapid7 #Poc #proofofconcept

posts.content:
Why you should care about the new JetBrains TeamCity authentication bypass vulnerability CVE-2024-27198 (9.8 critical):

  • On 18 October 2023, Microsoft observed North Korean state-sponsored APTs Diamond Sleet (aka Lazarus Group, publicly attributed to 110 Research Center 3rd Technical Surveillance Bureau of Reconnaissance General Bureau by the US Government) and Onyx Sleet (aka Andariel, also publicly attributed to RGB by the US Government) exploiting a similar JetBrains TeamCity authentication bypass vulnerability CVE-2023-42793.
  • On 13 December 2023, CISA published a cybersecurity advisory reporting that the Russian state-sponsored APT29 (Cozy Bear, publicly attributed to Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR) by the USG) was mass-exploiting CVE-2023-42793 since September 2023.
  • From public disclosure to proof of concept was 6 days. Exploitation was within 7 days after that (KEV Catalog in 15 days). Nation-state abuse within 12-22 days of public disclosure.

#JetBrains #TeamCity #vulnerability #securityadvisory #CVE_2024_27198 #CVE_2024_27199 #Rapid7 #Poc #proofofconcept

posts.content:
JetBrains tries to save face by responding to Rapid7's blog post with clarifications. It comes off accusatory and defends their attempt to silently patch. cc: @catc0n @campuscodi @serghei @jgreig
🔗 https://blog.jetbrains.com/teamcity/2024/03/our-approach-addressing-recently-discovered-vulnerabilities-in-teamcity-on-premises/

To reiterate, we never had any intention to release a fix silently without making the full details public. As a CVE Numbering Authority (CNA), we assigned CVE IDs for both issues a day after receiving the report.

We suggested disclosing the details of the vulnerabilities in the same way we have followed in the past (with a time delay between releasing a fix and making a full disclosure), which allows our customers to upgrade their TeamCity instances.

This suggestion was rejected by the Rapid7 team who published full details of the vulnerabilities (and how to exploit them) a few hours after we had released a fix to TeamCity customers.

#JetBrains #TeamCity #vulnerability #securityadvisory #CVE_2024_27198 #CVE_2024_27199 #Rapid7 #Poc #proofofconcept

posts.content:
Stole this idea from a recent viral thing, but I asked AI to announce JetBrains TeamCity to KEV today in the voice of Moira Rose:

"Darlings, gather round, for I have a tale of digital intrigue and subterfuge most foul. On this day, the cyber sentinels at CISA have unfurled their scrolls to reveal a new entrant upon their illustrious list of Known Exploited Vulnerabilities. The malefactor in question? CVE-2024-27198, a nefarious chink in the armor of JetBrains TeamCity, a bastion of collaborative ingenuity. This particular vulnerability, a sly bypass of authentication, empowers the unscrupulous to don the mantle of an administrator, wielding powers most administrative. Announced with a flourish and a modicum of drama on Monday, the vigilant watchers at GreyNoise have confirmed sightings of this exploit cavorting in the wild, a specter in the digital ether. Let us be on guard, for the digital realm is fraught with shadows and specters, ever lurking, ever waiting to pounce."

posts.content:
As most security folk are aware, TeamCity pushed out information on these two CVEs over the weekend. Both vulnerabilities are critical-class issues that would allow an attacker – unauthenticated, with merely HTTP(S) access – to bypass auth checks and get administrative control of the TeamCity server. CVE-2024-27198’s authentication bypass weighs in at a robust 9.8 CVSS base score; CVE-2024-27199, a relative path transversal issue, has no CVSS score [ETA: it does now; it's a 7.3, which is high-severity].

https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2024-27198
👁️

posts.content:
Stole this idea from a recent viral thing, but I asked AI to announce JetBrains TeamCity to KEV today in the voice of Moira Rose:

"Darlings, gather round, for I have a tale of digital intrigue and subterfuge most foul. On this day, the cyber sentinels at CISA have unfurled their scrolls to reveal a new entrant upon their illustrious list of Known Exploited Vulnerabilities. The malefactor in question? CVE-2024-27198, a nefarious chink in the armor of JetBrains TeamCity, a bastion of collaborative ingenuity. This particular vulnerability, a sly bypass of authentication, empowers the unscrupulous to don the mantle of an administrator, wielding powers most administrative. Announced with a flourish and a modicum of drama on Monday, the vigilant watchers at GreyNoise have confirmed sightings of this exploit cavorting in the wild, a specter in the digital ether. Let us be on guard, for the digital realm is fraught with shadows and specters, ever lurking, ever waiting to pounce."

posts.content:
Computer Weekly takes interest in the JetBrains-Rapid7 feud. "At the core of the disagreement lies a difference in approaches to vulnerability disclosure and patching." They neglected to mention JetBrains's explicitly stating "At this point, we made a decision not to make a coordinated disclosure with Rapid7"
🔗 https://www.computerweekly.com/news/366572453/Rapid7-hits-out-over-botched-vulnerability-disclosure

Shoutout to @todb who was quoted from a 2022 Rapid7 blog post:

With this in mind, said Beardsley, silent patching in fact limits knowledge of the patched vulnerability to skilled exploit developers, that is to say threat actors, so while it is true that silent patching cuts out casual, low-skilled hackers and script kiddies, it also excludes the good guys, legitimate pen testers, the developers of defensive technologies, incident responders, and the entire cyber community who might benefit from being able to understand the issue better and communicate it effectively.

#JetBrains #TeamCity #vulnerability #securityadvisory #CVE_2024_27198 #CVE_2024_27199 #Rapid7 #Poc #proofofconcept

posts.content:
Why you should care about the new JetBrains TeamCity authentication bypass vulnerability CVE-2024-27198 (9.8 critical):

  • On 18 October 2023, Microsoft observed North Korean state-sponsored APTs Diamond Sleet (aka Lazarus Group, publicly attributed to 110 Research Center 3rd Technical Surveillance Bureau of Reconnaissance General Bureau by the US Government) and Onyx Sleet (aka Andariel, also publicly attributed to RGB by the US Government) exploiting a similar JetBrains TeamCity authentication bypass vulnerability CVE-2023-42793.
  • On 13 December 2023, CISA published a cybersecurity advisory reporting that the Russian state-sponsored APT29 (Cozy Bear, publicly attributed to Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR) by the USG) was mass-exploiting CVE-2023-42793 since September 2023.
  • From public disclosure to proof of concept was 6 days. Exploitation was within 7 days after that (KEV Catalog in 15 days). Nation-state abuse within 12-22 days of public disclosure.

#JetBrains #TeamCity #vulnerability #securityadvisory #CVE_2024_27198 #CVE_2024_27199 #Rapid7 #Poc #proofofconcept

posts.content:
JetBrains tries to save face by responding to Rapid7's blog post with clarifications. It comes off accusatory and defends their attempt to silently patch. cc: @catc0n @campuscodi @serghei @jgreig
🔗 https://blog.jetbrains.com/teamcity/2024/03/our-approach-addressing-recently-discovered-vulnerabilities-in-teamcity-on-premises/

To reiterate, we never had any intention to release a fix silently without making the full details public. As a CVE Numbering Authority (CNA), we assigned CVE IDs for both issues a day after receiving the report.

We suggested disclosing the details of the vulnerabilities in the same way we have followed in the past (with a time delay between releasing a fix and making a full disclosure), which allows our customers to upgrade their TeamCity instances.

This suggestion was rejected by the Rapid7 team who published full details of the vulnerabilities (and how to exploit them) a few hours after we had released a fix to TeamCity customers.

#JetBrains #TeamCity #vulnerability #securityadvisory #CVE_2024_27198 #CVE_2024_27199 #Rapid7 #Poc #proofofconcept

posts.content:
Computer Weekly takes interest in the JetBrains-Rapid7 feud. "At the core of the disagreement lies a difference in approaches to vulnerability disclosure and patching." They neglected to mention JetBrains's explicitly stating "At this point, we made a decision not to make a coordinated disclosure with Rapid7"
🔗 https://www.computerweekly.com/news/366572453/Rapid7-hits-out-over-botched-vulnerability-disclosure

Shoutout to @todb who was quoted from a 2022 Rapid7 blog post:

With this in mind, said Beardsley, silent patching in fact limits knowledge of the patched vulnerability to skilled exploit developers, that is to say threat actors, so while it is true that silent patching cuts out casual, low-skilled hackers and script kiddies, it also excludes the good guys, legitimate pen testers, the developers of defensive technologies, incident responders, and the entire cyber community who might benefit from being able to understand the issue better and communicate it effectively.

#JetBrains #TeamCity #vulnerability #securityadvisory #CVE_2024_27198 #CVE_2024_27199 #Rapid7 #Poc #proofofconcept

posts.content:
Why you should care about the new JetBrains TeamCity authentication bypass vulnerability CVE-2024-27198 (9.8 critical):

  • On 18 October 2023, Microsoft observed North Korean state-sponsored APTs Diamond Sleet (aka Lazarus Group, publicly attributed to 110 Research Center 3rd Technical Surveillance Bureau of Reconnaissance General Bureau by the US Government) and Onyx Sleet (aka Andariel, also publicly attributed to RGB by the US Government) exploiting a similar JetBrains TeamCity authentication bypass vulnerability CVE-2023-42793.
  • On 13 December 2023, CISA published a cybersecurity advisory reporting that the Russian state-sponsored APT29 (Cozy Bear, publicly attributed to Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR) by the USG) was mass-exploiting CVE-2023-42793 since September 2023.
  • From public disclosure to proof of concept was 6 days. Exploitation was within 7 days after that (KEV Catalog in 15 days). Nation-state abuse within 12-22 days of public disclosure.

#JetBrains #TeamCity #vulnerability #securityadvisory #CVE_2024_27198 #CVE_2024_27199 #Rapid7 #Poc #proofofconcept

posts.content:
JetBrains tries to save face by responding to Rapid7's blog post with clarifications. It comes off accusatory and defends their attempt to silently patch. cc: @catc0n @campuscodi @serghei @jgreig
🔗 https://blog.jetbrains.com/teamcity/2024/03/our-approach-addressing-recently-discovered-vulnerabilities-in-teamcity-on-premises/

To reiterate, we never had any intention to release a fix silently without making the full details public. As a CVE Numbering Authority (CNA), we assigned CVE IDs for both issues a day after receiving the report.

We suggested disclosing the details of the vulnerabilities in the same way we have followed in the past (with a time delay between releasing a fix and making a full disclosure), which allows our customers to upgrade their TeamCity instances.

This suggestion was rejected by the Rapid7 team who published full details of the vulnerabilities (and how to exploit them) a few hours after we had released a fix to TeamCity customers.

#JetBrains #TeamCity #vulnerability #securityadvisory #CVE_2024_27198 #CVE_2024_27199 #Rapid7 #Poc #proofofconcept

posts.content:
The best option is for anyone using the on-prem version of the platform to upgrade immediately to version 2023.11.4 – all versions prior to that are vulnerable. Second-best option is to apply a plug-in patch, which the company’s also made available, until the full upgrade can be done.

https://blog.jetbrains.com/teamcity/2024/03/additional-critical-security-issues-affecting-teamcity-on-premises-cve-2024-27198-and-cve-2024-27199-update-to-2023-11-4-now/

posts.content:
As most security folk are aware, TeamCity pushed out information on these two CVEs over the weekend. Both vulnerabilities are critical-class issues that would allow an attacker – unauthenticated, with merely HTTP(S) access – to bypass auth checks and get administrative control of the TeamCity server. CVE-2024-27198’s authentication bypass weighs in at a robust 9.8 CVSS base score; CVE-2024-27199, a relative path transversal issue, has no CVSS score [ETA: it does now; it's a 7.3, which is high-severity].

https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2024-27198
👁️

posts.content:
If you read between the lines on the JetBrains and Rapid7 story, you'll see that JetBrains decided to cut Rapid7 out of the loop on Feb 23, but told Rapid7 that they're "still investigating" on Mar 1.

However you feel about PoCs, technical details, disclosure, etc., it's super inappropriate to lie to researchers who disclosed this to you responsibly about what your plans are.

posts.content:
If you read between the lines on the JetBrains and Rapid7 story, you'll see that JetBrains decided to cut Rapid7 out of the loop on Feb 23, but told Rapid7 that they're "still investigating" on Mar 1.

However you feel about PoCs, technical details, disclosure, etc., it's super inappropriate to lie to researchers who disclosed this to you responsibly about what your plans are.

Refs:

  • https://www.rapid7.com/blog/post/2024/03/04/etr-cve-2024-27198-and-cve-2024-27199-jetbrains-teamcity-multiple-authentication-bypass-vulnerabilities-fixed/

posts.content:
We're still discovering further ramifications to #Ivanti's #PulseSecure vulnerabilities (#CVE_2023_46805 & #CVE_2024_21887). In February, we identified two new backdoors: #SparkCockpit & #SparkTar. Both backdoors employ selective interception of TLS communication, offer multiple degrees of persistence and access possibilities into the victim network (e.g., traffic tunneling through SOCKS proxy).

👀 Analysis & detection rules at https://blog.nviso.eu/2024/03/01/covert-tls-n-day-backdoors-sparkcockpit-sparktar/

The findings of our investigation have been independently corroborated by the research performed by Mandiant and have partially been observed by Fortinet.

#threatintel #forensics #reverseengineering

posts.content:
Hot off the press! CISA along with FBI, MS-ISAC, Australia ASD ACSC, NCSC-UK, NCSC-NZ, Canadian Centre for Cyber Security and CERT NZ release joint cybersecurity advisory Threat Actors Exploit Multiple Vulnerabilities in Ivanti Connect Secure and Policy Secure Gateways. It includes TTPs, IOCs, and detection methods to help network defenders mitigate risk.
🔗 https://www.cisa.gov/news-events/cybersecurity-advisories/aa24-060b

Of particular concern, the authoring organizations and industry partners have determined that cyber threat actors are able to deceive Ivanti’s internal and external Integrity Checker Tool (ICT), resulting in a failure to detect compromise.

During multiple incident response engagements associated with this activity, CISA identified that Ivanti’s internal and previous external ICT failed to detect compromise. In addition, CISA has conducted independent research in a lab environment validating that the Ivanti ICT is not sufficient to detect compromise and that a cyber threat actor may be able to gain root-level persistence despite issuing factory resets.

The authoring organizations strongly urge all organizations to consider the significant risk of adversary access to, and persistence on, Ivanti Connect Secure and Ivanti Policy Secure gateways when determining whether to continue operating these devices in an enterprise environment.

cc: @campuscodi @briankrebs @deepthoughts10 @serghei @selenalarson @DaveMWilburn

#cyberespionage #IOC #TTPs #UNC5325 #China #Ivanti #ConnectSecure #vulnerability #zeroday #eitw #activeexploitation #UTA0178 #UNC5221 #CVE_2023_46805 #CVE_2024_21887 #KEV #KnownExploitedVulnerabilitiesCatalog #CISA #CVE_2024_21888 #CVE_2024_22024 #CISA #securityadvisory

account.note:
Current open-source cyber threat intelligence, critical vulnerabilities, zero-days, proofs of concept, cybercrime/cyberespionage, threat actors/APTs, IOCs, and other cybersecurity and intelligence news.

(Alt-text for banner: white and brown goat on left side facing a white and black goat looking towards camera)
(Alt-text for avatar: screaming goat with tongue hanging out, with a rainbow in the background)

posts.content:
This line from Mandiant's article stuck out to me: "In addition, we have seen the threat actor demonstrate a nuanced understanding of the appliance and their ability to subvert detection throughout this campaign."

The reason is because of the following:

The internal ICT is configured to run in two-hour intervals by default and is meant to be run in conjunction with continuous monitoring. Any malicious file system modifications made and reverted between the two-hour scan intervals would remain undetected by the ICT. When the activation and deactivation routines are performed tactfully in quick succession, it can minimize the risk of ICT detection by timing the activation routine to coincide precisely with the intended use of the BUSHWALK webshell.

This sentence also concerns me, giving me flashbacks to Eclypsium's article

An encrypted version of BUSHWALK is placed in a directory excluded by the integrity checker tool (ICT)

posts.content:
Hot off the press! CISA along with FBI, MS-ISAC, Australia ASD ACSC, NCSC-UK, NCSC-NZ, Canadian Centre for Cyber Security and CERT NZ release joint cybersecurity advisory Threat Actors Exploit Multiple Vulnerabilities in Ivanti Connect Secure and Policy Secure Gateways. It includes TTPs, IOCs, and detection methods to help network defenders mitigate risk.
🔗 https://www.cisa.gov/news-events/cybersecurity-advisories/aa24-060b

Of particular concern, the authoring organizations and industry partners have determined that cyber threat actors are able to deceive Ivanti’s internal and external Integrity Checker Tool (ICT), resulting in a failure to detect compromise.

During multiple incident response engagements associated with this activity, CISA identified that Ivanti’s internal and previous external ICT failed to detect compromise. In addition, CISA has conducted independent research in a lab environment validating that the Ivanti ICT is not sufficient to detect compromise and that a cyber threat actor may be able to gain root-level persistence despite issuing factory resets.

The authoring organizations strongly urge all organizations to consider the significant risk of adversary access to, and persistence on, Ivanti Connect Secure and Ivanti Policy Secure gateways when determining whether to continue operating these devices in an enterprise environment.

cc: @campuscodi @briankrebs @deepthoughts10 @serghei @selenalarson @DaveMWilburn

#cyberespionage #IOC #TTPs #UNC5325 #China #Ivanti #ConnectSecure #vulnerability #zeroday #eitw #activeexploitation #UTA0178 #UNC5221 #CVE_2023_46805 #CVE_2024_21887 #KEV #KnownExploitedVulnerabilitiesCatalog #CISA #CVE_2024_21888 #CVE_2024_22024 #CISA #securityadvisory

posts.content:
This line from Mandiant's article stuck out to me: "In addition, we have seen the threat actor demonstrate a nuanced understanding of the appliance and their ability to subvert detection throughout this campaign."

The reason is because of the following:

The internal ICT is configured to run in two-hour intervals by default and is meant to be run in conjunction with continuous monitoring. Any malicious file system modifications made and reverted between the two-hour scan intervals would remain undetected by the ICT. When the activation and deactivation routines are performed tactfully in quick succession, it can minimize the risk of ICT detection by timing the activation routine to coincide precisely with the intended use of the BUSHWALK webshell.

This sentence also concerns me, giving me flashbacks to Eclypsium's article

An encrypted version of BUSHWALK is placed in a directory excluded by the integrity checker tool (ICT)

posts.content:
We're still discovering further ramifications to #Ivanti's #PulseSecure vulnerabilities (#CVE_2023_46805 & #CVE_2024_21887). In February, we identified two new backdoors: #SparkCockpit & #SparkTar. Both backdoors employ selective interception of TLS communication, offer multiple degrees of persistence and access possibilities into the victim network (e.g., traffic tunneling through SOCKS proxy).

👀 Analysis & detection rules at https://blog.nviso.eu/2024/03/01/covert-tls-n-day-backdoors-sparkcockpit-sparktar/

The findings of our investigation have been independently corroborated by the research performed by Mandiant and have partially been observed by Fortinet.

#threatintel #forensics #reverseengineering

posts.content:
Akamai reports on a Mirai malware variant called NetKiller.Condi Botnet exploiting CVE-2024-0778 (9.8 critical), an OS command injection in Zhejiang Uniview ISC camera model 2500-S. The threat actor behind the attacks also targeted other URIs with different payloads, indicating that multiple system architectures are being targeted. C2 IP associated with the attacks are based in Vietnam. The earliest known reference to this activity dates back to June 28, 2023, indicating a prolonged and evolving threat. IOC provided.
🔗 https://www.akamai.com/blog/security-research/netkiller-condi-botnet-exploits-camera

#Mirai #Condi #botnet #CVE_2024_0778 #Uniview #threatintel #IOC

CVE-2024-0778.description: ** UNSUPPORTED WHEN ASSIGNED ** A vulnerability, which was classified as critical, has been found in Uniview ISC 2500-S up to 20210930. Affected by this issue is the function setNatConfig of the file /Interface/DevManage/VM.php. The manipulation of the argument natAddress/natPort/natServerPort leads to os command injection. The exploit has been disclosed to the public and may be used. The identifier of this vulnerability is VDB-251696. NOTE: This vulnerability only affects products that are no longer supported by the maintainer. NOTE: Vendor was contacted early and confirmed immediately that the product is end-of-life. It should be retired and replaced.

posts.content:
Hot off the press! CISA along with FBI, MS-ISAC, Australia ASD ACSC, NCSC-UK, NCSC-NZ, Canadian Centre for Cyber Security and CERT NZ release joint cybersecurity advisory Threat Actors Exploit Multiple Vulnerabilities in Ivanti Connect Secure and Policy Secure Gateways. It includes TTPs, IOCs, and detection methods to help network defenders mitigate risk.
🔗 https://www.cisa.gov/news-events/cybersecurity-advisories/aa24-060b

Of particular concern, the authoring organizations and industry partners have determined that cyber threat actors are able to deceive Ivanti’s internal and external Integrity Checker Tool (ICT), resulting in a failure to detect compromise.

During multiple incident response engagements associated with this activity, CISA identified that Ivanti’s internal and previous external ICT failed to detect compromise. In addition, CISA has conducted independent research in a lab environment validating that the Ivanti ICT is not sufficient to detect compromise and that a cyber threat actor may be able to gain root-level persistence despite issuing factory resets.

The authoring organizations strongly urge all organizations to consider the significant risk of adversary access to, and persistence on, Ivanti Connect Secure and Ivanti Policy Secure gateways when determining whether to continue operating these devices in an enterprise environment.

cc: @campuscodi @briankrebs @deepthoughts10 @serghei @selenalarson @DaveMWilburn

posts.content:
This line from Mandiant's article stuck out to me: "In addition, we have seen the threat actor demonstrate a nuanced understanding of the appliance and their ability to subvert detection throughout this campaign."

The reason is because of the following:

The internal ICT is configured to run in two-hour intervals by default and is meant to be run in conjunction with continuous monitoring. Any malicious file system modifications made and reverted between the two-hour scan intervals would remain undetected by the ICT. When the activation and deactivation routines are performed tactfully in quick succession, it can minimize the risk of ICT detection by timing the activation routine to coincide precisely with the intended use of the BUSHWALK webshell.

This sentence also concerns me, giving me flashbacks to Eclypsium's article

An encrypted version of BUSHWALK is placed in a directory excluded by the integrity checker tool (ICT)

posts.content:
Increased scrutiny on Microsoft as @dangoodin writes for Ars Technica: Hackers exploited Windows 0-day for 6 months after Microsoft knew of it. Microsoft only announced two exploited zero-days during their February 2024 Patch Tuesday, but botched an update to a third exploited zero-day CVE-2024-21410 (accidentally updating CVE-2024-21413 instead). Now, Avast claimed that CVE-2024-21338 was exploited in the wild since at least August 2023 (date that they notified Microsoft with a PoC).

posts.content:
Microsoft Security Response Center (MSRC) quietly updated its security advisory for CVE-2024-21338 following the Avast blog post on 28 February 2024 claiming zero-day exploitation. Version 1.2 for Feb 28, 2024 reads "Updated the Exploitability Index to 0 - Exploitation Detected and Exploited to Yes. This is an informational change only."

Analyst Note: This quiet update did not occur on 28 February as suggested, as multiple people in the infosec community were checking it, and the RSS feed for it did not get updated. This puts the total number of exploited zero-days in February 2024 up to FOUR.
🔗 https://msrc.microsoft.com/update-guide/vulnerability/CVE-2024-21338

posts.content:
@todb you're responding to an automated account. I've read the website's blog posts, and while they provide quick commentary, it lacks substance in my opinion.

Yeah I had issues with how Avast keeps calling it a zero-day but there's no timeline available, and that Microsoft does not list it as Exploited.

"We developed a custom PoC (Proof of Concept) exploit and submitted it in August 2023 as part of a vulnerability report to Microsoft, leading to an advisory for CVE-2024-21338 in the February Patch Tuesday update."

They sat on what they call an ITW 0-day for at least 6 months if we take that quote at face value.

account.note:
Shmethical #Hacker. #Election Judge. #CVE mucker-abouter. #Metasploit collaborator. #FriendofDeSoto. #Podcaster (see @podsothoth and @hotforteacher).

posts.content:
@todb you're responding to an automated account. I've read the website's blog posts, and while they provide quick commentary, it lacks substance in my opinion.

Yeah I had issues with how Avast keeps calling it a zero-day but there's no timeline available, and that Microsoft does not list it as Exploited.

"We developed a custom PoC (Proof of Concept) exploit and submitted it in August 2023 as part of a vulnerability report to Microsoft, leading to an advisory for CVE-2024-21338 in the February Patch Tuesday update."

They sat on what they call an ITW 0-day for at least 6 months if we take that quote at face value.

posts.content:
CVE-2020-15778 was published a few years ago, to document a remote code injection issue in the scp binary (part of OpenSSH 8.3p1 and older). The CVE has been updated a few times over the years. Red Hat has been making updates to OpenSSH and as part of that process uncovered a few additional vulnerabilities (CVE-2018-2068, CVE-2019-6111).

Red Hat and other vendors are recommending the use of rsync with SSH instead of scp, because the issues are not going to be fixed due to the patches breaking several uses cases. These issues are being detected by popular vulnerability scanning platforms as Nessus Plugin ID 159492 and Qualys QID 105936.

TL;DR – Stop using scp and start using rsync with SSH.

Command syntax to help you:

OLD – scp file user@host:/path/to/remote/file.txt
NEW – rsync -av -e ssh file user@host:/path/to/file.txt

(the -e ssh option instructs rsync to connect to a remote system over SSH).

#scp #rsync #linux #infosec #cybersecurity #vulnerability

References:
https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2020-15778
https://access.redhat.com/articles/5284081
https://www.tenable.com/plugins/nessus/159492
https://success.qualys.com/discussions/s/question/0D52L00005S49GjSAJ/how-to-solve-openssh-command-injection-vulnerability-qid105936-vulnerability

CVE-2019-6111.description: An issue was discovered in OpenSSH 7.9. Due to the scp implementation being derived from 1983 rcp, the server chooses which files/directories are sent to the client. However, the scp client only performs cursory validation of the object name returned (only directory traversal attacks are prevented). A malicious scp server (or Man-in-The-Middle attacker) can overwrite arbitrary files in the scp client target directory. If recursive operation (-r) is performed, the server can manipulate subdirectories as well (for example, to overwrite the .ssh/authorized_keys file).

posts.content:
It is with great relish that we announce the v24.03.0 release of Malcolm, a powerful, easily deployable network traffic analysis tool suite.

Although the previous Malcolm release came out just a few weeks ago, the Malcolm development team felt there was enough new goodness to cut an early March release. This release contains new features, bug fixes and component version updates, including:

  • Support for JSON-delimited Zeek log ingestion (issue #65)
    • JSON format logs generated by Zeek instances external to Malcolm can now be ingested by Malcolm, either by forwarding them with a tool like filebeat or Fluent Bit or by uploading an archive file containing the log files. While Malcolm still generates TSV-formatted Zeek logs internally by default, it can be configured to create JSON format Zeek logs as well.
  • Created new dashboards for other non-network and third-party log data (issue #414)
    • While Malcolm's main focus is analyzing network traffic log metadata (generated by Zeek, Arkime, and Suricata), it can also receive and index logs from other sources, such as:
      • System resource utilization metrics (CPU, memory, disk, network, etc.)
      • System temperatures
      • Linux system logs
      • Windows event logs
      • Process or service health status
      • Logs appended to textual log files (e.g., tail-ing a log file)
      • The output of an external script or program
      • Messages in the form of MQTT control packets
      • many more…
    • This release revamped some existing dashboards and added several new ones to visualize some of these common third-party and host logs.
  • Container security review (issue #236)
    • Malcolm's container images are automatically scanned by Trivy as they are build as part of our CI workflows. This release entailed an in-depth review of the results from the latest scans which resulted in resolving most of the outstanding issues found.
  • Support /attributes and /events enpoints from MISP feed for Zeek intel generation (issue #336)
    • This release expands Malcolm's ability to pull from MISP feeds to generate Zeek intel files. When Malcolm connects to user-provided URLs for the MISP feeds, it will attempt to determine the format of the data served and process it accordingly. This could be presented as:
      • a manifest JSON file
      • a directory listing containing a file named manifest.json
      • a directory listing of JSON files without a manifest.json file
      • a list of Events returned for a request via the MISP Automation API made to a MISP platform's /events endpoint
      • a list of Attributes returned for a request via the MISP Automation API made to a MISP platform's /attributes endpoint
    • In addition to MISP, STIX™ v2.0/v2.1 indicators and TAXII™ 2.0/2.1 feeds are supported as well.
  • Added Suricata rules to detect Unitronics VisiLogic CVE-2023-6448 (issue #394) from the DHS CISA Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog
  • Minor tweaks to the new Malcolm landing page (issue #427)
  • Incorporated a new ICSNPP Profinet IO CM network protocol analyzer (issue #429)
  • Version updates to some major Malcolm components:
    • Arkime to v5.0.1
    • OpenSearch and OpenSearch Dashboards to v2.12.0
  • A handful of bug fixes:
    • fixed the way we handle false values in environment variables in local.zeek (issue #413)
    • addressed a few issues with the install.py script when installing from downloaeded GitHub release artifacts (issue #416)
    • fixed a condition in which the htadmin was creating htpasswd file entries without a newline between them (issue #426)
    • removed a hard-coded date value in Arkime-to-Kibana pivot links (issue #428)
    • corrected unencrypted, unzipped extracted file download not working in the extracted files interface (issue #431)
    • a few fixes to the Raspberry Pi 4 build of Hedgehog Linux

Keep your eyes open, because there's lots more on the way in the coming months, including a bunch of end-user training topics for which we hope to develop training/documentation/videos. If you've got suggestions, we want to hear them.

Malcolm and Hedgehog Linux may be obtained by pulling or building the Docker images and/or building the ISO installer images as described in the documentation. Unofficial ISO installer images for Malcolm and Hedgehog Linux are not hosted on GitHub, but may be downloaded from https://malcolm.fyi/.

#Malcolm #HedgehogLinux #Zeek #Arkime #NetBox #OpenSearch #Elasticsearch #Suricata #PCAP #NetworkTrafficAnalysis #networksecuritymonitoring #OT #ICS #icssecurity #CyberSecurity #Cyber #Infosec #GitHub #INL #DHS #CISA #CISAgov #Kubernetes #Docker #raspberrypi

posts.content: @mttaggart remember that time the civilian government agency CISA assigned a CVE ID for a default password vulnerability (CVE-2023-6448 for reference) and put it into the KEV Catalog? #CVECrowdDeny

posts.content:
It is with great relish that we announce the v24.03.0 release of Malcolm, a powerful, easily deployable network traffic analysis tool suite.

Although the previous Malcolm release came out just a few weeks ago, the Malcolm development team felt there was enough new goodness to cut an early March release. This release contains new features, bug fixes and component version updates, including:

  • Support for JSON-delimited Zeek log ingestion (issue #65)
    • JSON format logs generated by Zeek instances external to Malcolm can now be ingested by Malcolm, either by forwarding them with a tool like filebeat or Fluent Bit or by uploading an archive file containing the log files. While Malcolm still generates TSV-formatted Zeek logs internally by default, it can be configured to create JSON format Zeek logs as well.
  • Created new dashboards for other non-network and third-party log data (issue #414)
    • While Malcolm's main focus is analyzing network traffic log metadata (generated by Zeek, Arkime, and Suricata), it can also receive and index logs from other sources, such as:
      • System resource utilization metrics (CPU, memory, disk, network, etc.)
      • System temperatures
      • Linux system logs
      • Windows event logs
      • Process or service health status
      • Logs appended to textual log files (e.g., tail-ing a log file)
      • The output of an external script or program
      • Messages in the form of MQTT control packets
      • many more…
    • This release revamped some existing dashboards and added several new ones to visualize some of these common third-party and host logs.
  • Container security review (issue #236)
    • Malcolm's container images are automatically scanned by Trivy as they are build as part of our CI workflows. This release entailed an in-depth review of the results from the latest scans which resulted in resolving most of the outstanding issues found.
  • Support /attributes and /events enpoints from MISP feed for Zeek intel generation (issue #336)
    • This release expands Malcolm's ability to pull from MISP feeds to generate Zeek intel files. When Malcolm connects to user-provided URLs for the MISP feeds, it will attempt to determine the format of the data served and process it accordingly. This could be presented as:
      • a manifest JSON file
      • a directory listing containing a file named manifest.json
      • a directory listing of JSON files without a manifest.json file
      • a list of Events returned for a request via the MISP Automation API made to a MISP platform's /events endpoint
      • a list of Attributes returned for a request via the MISP Automation API made to a MISP platform's /attributes endpoint
    • In addition to MISP, STIX™ v2.0/v2.1 indicators and TAXII™ 2.0/2.1 feeds are supported as well.
  • Added Suricata rules to detect Unitronics VisiLogic CVE-2023-6448 (issue #394) from the DHS CISA Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog
  • Minor tweaks to the new Malcolm landing page (issue #427)
  • Incorporated a new ICSNPP Profinet IO CM network protocol analyzer (issue #429)
  • Version updates to some major Malcolm components:
    • Arkime to v5.0.1
    • OpenSearch and OpenSearch Dashboards to v2.12.0
  • A handful of bug fixes:
    • fixed the way we handle false values in environment variables in local.zeek (issue #413)
    • addressed a few issues with the install.py script when installing from downloaeded GitHub release artifacts (issue #416)
    • fixed a condition in which the htadmin was creating htpasswd file entries without a newline between them (issue #426)
    • removed a hard-coded date value in Arkime-to-Kibana pivot links (issue #428)
    • corrected unencrypted, unzipped extracted file download not working in the extracted files interface (issue #431)
    • a few fixes to the Raspberry Pi 4 build of Hedgehog Linux

Keep your eyes open, because there's lots more on the way in the coming months, including a bunch of end-user training topics for which we hope to develop training/documentation/videos. If you've got suggestions, we want to hear them.

Malcolm and Hedgehog Linux may be obtained by pulling or building the Docker images and/or building the ISO installer images as described in the documentation. Unofficial ISO installer images for Malcolm and Hedgehog Linux are not hosted on GitHub, but may be downloaded from https://malcolm.fyi/.

#Malcolm #HedgehogLinux #Zeek #Arkime #NetBox #OpenSearch #Elasticsearch #Suricata #PCAP #NetworkTrafficAnalysis #networksecuritymonitoring #OT #ICS #icssecurity #CyberSecurity #Cyber #Infosec #GitHub #INL #DHS #CISA #CISAgov #Kubernetes #Docker #raspberrypi

CVE-2023-6448.description: Unitronics Vision Series PLCs and HMIs use default administrative passwords. An unauthenticated attacker with network access to a PLC or HMI can take administrative control of the system.

posts.content:
#iOS 17.4 includes 4 important #security fixes, 2 were exploited

Update ASAP.

Zero-day exploits for a kernel flaw (CVE-2024-23225) and RTKit flaw (CVE-2024-23296), both when exploited bypassed kernel memory protections have been patched by #Apple.

Also a #privacy patch included in the Accessibility feature (CVE-2024-23243); apps could read "sensitive location information" and a bug in Safari Private Browsing exposed locked tabs while switching tab groups (CVE-2024-23256).

Other security fixes are also included in iOS 17.4, but the additional CVE entries will be added later.

#cybersecurity #update #exploitation #cve

https://9to5mac.com/2024/03/05/ios-17-4-fixes-4-security-flaws/

posts.content:
@campuscodi Apple put that information all over this security advisory, making it hard to decipher. It's an AirDrop vulnerability in Accessibility, that could allow an app to read sensitive location information (labeled as privacy issue). CVE-2024-23243 (not exploited in the wild) was addressed with improved private data redaction for log entries. Cristian Dinca of "Tudor Vianu" National High School of Computer Science, Romania is credited for reporting this vulnerability, great job.

#Apple #vulnerability #PatchTuesday #CVE_2024_23243

CVE-2023-36049.description: # Microsoft Security Advisory CVE-2023-36049: .NET Elevation of Privilege Vulnerability ## Executive summary Microsoft is releasing this security advisory to provide information about a vulnerability in .NET 6.0, .NET 7.0 and .NET 8.0 RC2. This advisory also provides guidance on what developers can do to update their applications to address this vulnerability. An elevation of privilege vulnerability exists in .NET where untrusted URIs provided to System.Net.WebRequest.Create can be used to inject arbitrary commands to backend FTP servers. ## Announcement Announcement for this issue can be found at https://github.com/dotnet/announcements/issues/287 ### Mitigation factors Microsoft has not identified any mitigating factors for this vulnerability. ## Affected software * Any .NET 6.0 application running on .NET 6.0.24 or earlier. * Any .NET 7.0 application running on .NET 7.0.13 or earlier. * Any .NET 8.0 application running on .NET 8.0 RC2. ## Advisory FAQ ### How do I know if I am affected? If you have a runtime or SDK with a version listed, or an affected package listed in [affected software](#affected-software), you're exposed to the vulnerability. ### How do I fix the issue? * To fix the issue please install the latest version of .NET 8.0 or .NET 7.0 or .NET 6.0. If you have installed one or more .NET SDKs through Visual Studio, Visual Studio will prompt you to update Visual Studio, which will also update your .NET SDKs. * If you are using one of the affected packages, please update to the patched version listed above. * If you have .NET 6.0 or greater installed, you can list the versions you have installed by running the `dotnet --info` command. You will see output like the following; ``` .NET Core SDK (reflecting any global.json): Version: 6.0.200 Commit: 8473146e7d Runtime Environment: OS Name: Windows OS Version: 10.0.18363 OS Platform: Windows RID: win10-x64 Base Path: C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk\6.0.300\ Host (useful for support): Version: 6.0.5 Commit: 8473146e7d .NET Core SDKs installed: 6.0.200 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk] .NET Core runtimes installed: Microsoft.AspNetCore.App 6.0.5 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\shared\Microsoft.AspNetCore.App] Microsoft.NETCore.App 6.0.5 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\shared\Microsoft.NETCore.App] Microsoft.WindowsDesktop.App 6.0.5 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\shared\Microsoft.WindowsDesktop.App] To install additional .NET Core runtimes or SDKs: https://aka.ms/dotnet-download ``` * If you're using .NET 8.0, you should download and install .NET 8.0.0 Runtime or .NET 8.0.100 SDK (for Visual Studio 2022 v17.8) from https://dotnet.microsoft.com/download/dotnet-core/8.0. * If you're using .NET 7.0, you should download and install Runtime 7.0.14 or SDK 7.0.114 (for Visual Studio 2022 v17.4) from https://dotnet.microsoft.com/download/dotnet-core/7.0. * If you're using .NET 6.0, you should download and install Runtime 6.0.25 or SDK 6.0.317 (for Visual Studio 2022 v17.2) from https://dotnet.microsoft.com/download/dotnet-core/6.0. .NET 6.0 and .NET 7.0 updates are also available from Microsoft Update. To access this either type "Check for updates" in your Windows search, or open Settings, choose Update & Security and then click Check for Updates. Once you have installed the updated runtime or SDK, restart your apps for the update to take effect. Additionally, if you've deployed [self-contained applications](https://docs.microsoft.com/dotnet/core/deploying/#self-contained-deployments-scd) targeting any of the impacted versions, these applications are also vulnerable and must be recompiled and redeployed. ## Other Information ### Reporting Security Issues If you have found a potential security issue in .NET 8.0 or .NET 7.0 or .NET 6.0, please email details to secure@microsoft.com. Reports may qualify for the Microsoft .NET Core & .NET 5 Bounty. Details of the Microsoft .NET Bounty Program including terms and conditions are at . ### Support You can ask questions about this issue on GitHub in the .NET GitHub organization. The main repos are located at https://github.com/dotnet/runtime and https://github.com/dotnet/aspnet/. The Announcements repo (https://github.com/dotnet/Announcements) will contain this bulletin as an issue and will include a link to a discussion issue. You can ask questions in the linked discussion issue. ### Disclaimer The information provided in this advisory is provided "as is" without warranty of any kind. Microsoft disclaims all warranties, either express or implied, including the warranties of merchantability and fitness for a particular purpose. In no event shall Microsoft Corporation or its suppliers be liable for any damages whatsoever including direct, indirect, incidental, consequential, loss of business profits or special damages, even if Microsoft Corporation or its suppliers have been advised of the possibility of such damages. Some states do not allow the exclusion or limitation of liability for consequential or incidental damages so the foregoing limitation may not apply. ### External Links [CVE-2023-36049]( https://www.cve.org/CVERecord?id=CVE-2023-36049) ### Revisions V1.0 (November 14, 2023): Advisory published. _Version 1.0_ _Last Updated 2023-11-14_

posts.content:
ASEC reports that financially motivated threat actor z0Miner targets Korean Oracle WebLogic servers to cryptomine. z0Miner is known to exploit Oracle RCE vulnerabilities CVE-2020-14882 and CVE-2020-14883. ASEC provides the attack chain, from exploiting the vulnerabilities to deploy webshells, to using Fast Reverse Proxy (FRP) for Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) communication. Apache ActiveMQ vulnerability CVE-2023-46604 is also exploited. Netcat and AnyDesk are downloaded, and XMrig is used for mining. ASEC provides IOC, Monero Wallet and Mining Pool Address.
🔗 https://asec.ahnlab.com/en/62564/

#cybercrime #cryptojacking #threatintel #IOC #CVE_2020_14882 #CVE_2020_14883 #FRP #CVE_2023_46696 #z0Miner

CVE-2023-46604.description:
Apache ActiveMQ is vulnerable to Remote Code Execution.The vulnerability may allow a remote attacker with network access to a broker to run arbitrary shell commands by manipulating serialized class types in the OpenWire protocol to cause the broker to instantiate any class on the classpath. 

Users are recommended to upgrade to version 5.15.16, 5.16.7, 5.17.6, or 5.18.3, which fixes this issue.

posts.content:
Why you should care about the new JetBrains TeamCity authentication bypass vulnerability CVE-2024-27198 (9.8 critical):

  • On 18 October 2023, Microsoft observed North Korean state-sponsored APTs Diamond Sleet (aka Lazarus Group, publicly attributed to 110 Research Center 3rd Technical Surveillance Bureau of Reconnaissance General Bureau by the US Government) and Onyx Sleet (aka Andariel, also publicly attributed to RGB by the US Government) exploiting a similar JetBrains TeamCity authentication bypass vulnerability CVE-2023-42793.
  • On 13 December 2023, CISA published a cybersecurity advisory reporting that the Russian state-sponsored APT29 (Cozy Bear, publicly attributed to Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR) by the USG) was mass-exploiting CVE-2023-42793 since September 2023.
  • From public disclosure to proof of concept was 6 days. Exploitation was within 7 days after that (KEV Catalog in 15 days). Nation-state abuse within 12-22 days of public disclosure.

#JetBrains #TeamCity #vulnerability #securityadvisory #CVE_2024_27198 #CVE_2024_27199 #Rapid7 #Poc #proofofconcept

posts.content:
Increased scrutiny on Microsoft as @dangoodin writes for Ars Technica: Hackers exploited Windows 0-day for 6 months after Microsoft knew of it. Microsoft only announced two exploited zero-days during their February 2024 Patch Tuesday, but botched an update to a third exploited zero-day CVE-2024-21410 (accidentally updating CVE-2024-21413 instead). Now, Avast claimed that CVE-2024-21338 was exploited in the wild since at least August 2023 (date that they notified Microsoft with a PoC).

#CISA #KEV #CVE_2024_21338 #vulnerability #IOCTL #EoP #Avast #eitw #activeexploitation #MSRC #Microsoft

posts.content:
Increased scrutiny on Microsoft as @dangoodin writes for Ars Technica: Hackers exploited Windows 0-day for 6 months after Microsoft knew of it. Microsoft only announced two exploited zero-days during their February 2024 Patch Tuesday, but botched an update to a third exploited zero-day CVE-2024-21410 (accidentally updating CVE-2024-21413 instead). Now, Avast claimed that CVE-2024-21338 was exploited in the wild since at least August 2023 (date that they notified Microsoft with a PoC).

#CISA #KEV #CVE_2024_21338 #vulnerability #IOCTL #EoP #Avast #eitw #activeexploitation #MSRC #Microsoft

posts.content:
Mozilla Foundation Security Advisory 2024-11: Security Vulnerabilities fixed in Thunderbird 115.8.1. CVE-2024-1936 (high severity) Leaking of encrypted email subjects to other conversations. No mention of exploitation.
🔗 https://www.mozilla.org/en-US/security/advisories/mfsa2024-11/

#Mozilla #Thunderbird #vulnerability #CVE_2024_1936

CVE-2024-1936.description: The encrypted subject of an email message could be incorrectly and permanently assigned to an arbitrary other email message in Thunderbird's local cache. Consequently, when replying to the contaminated email message, the user might accidentally leak the confidential subject to a third party. While this update fixes the bug and avoids future message contamination, it does not automatically repair existing contaminations. Users are advised to use the repair folder functionality, which is available from the context menu of email folders, which will erase incorrect subject assignments. This vulnerability affects Thunderbird < 115.8.1.

posts.content:
When running local LLMs, some care should be taken when using untrusted models.

An obvious problem exists with models that include unsafe format like "pickle" for serializing their weights (https://jfrog.com/blog/data-scientists-targeted-by-malicious-hugging-face-ml-models-with-silent-backdoor/).

Fortunately, most models now are using safetensors or .gguf, which do not require code execution. However, even with these safe formats, bugs in the inference engines can be exploited.

For instance, llama.cpp recently fixed some overflows that could be exploited by a malicious .gguf to run arbitrary code:
* https://www.cve.org/CVERecord?id=CVE-2024-23496
* https://www.cve.org/CVERecord?id=CVE-2024-21802
* https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2024-21836

That is not surprising, but it is a reminder to keep software up-to-date - including inference engines.

When running agents that use generative AI (e.g. via APIs like ChatGPT or Gemini), there are also new attack vectors being found.Recently, the Morris II AI Prompt Worm demonstrates an attack on email assistance agents:

https://sites.google.com/view/compromptmized

#security #llm #ai #llamacpp

CVE-2024-23496.description: A heap-based buffer overflow vulnerability exists in the GGUF library gguf_fread_str functionality of llama.cpp Commit 18c2e17. A specially crafted .gguf file can lead to code execution. An attacker can provide a malicious file to trigger this vulnerability.
